head.title: Packing Material Takes a Back Seat

hedline.hl1: Packing Material Takes a Back Seat

abstract.p: Pressed polypropylene foam, humble packing material used to protect products in shipping, has been innovatively adapted to furniture by London designer Ross Lovegrove; photo (Currents column) (S)

block.p: Pressed polypropylene foam, the humble packing material used to protect products in shipping, has been innovatively adapted to furniture by the London designer Ross Lovegrove. The lightweight and stackable Air One lounge chair ($530), below, and Air Two stool ($115 each), left, were manufactured in Italy by Edra, a company known for its innovative use of transparent plastic and coated metallic paper for upholstery.

Pressed polypropylene foam, the humble packing material used to protect products in shipping, has been innovatively adapted to furniture by the London designer Ross Lovegrove. The lightweight and stackable Air One lounge chair ($530), below, and Air Two stool ($115 each), left, were manufactured in Italy by Edra, a company known for its innovative use of transparent plastic and coated metallic paper for upholstery.

Think of these stools and chairs as giant Styrofoam coffee cups just waiting to be called into service as seating. Mr. Lovegrove's pieces in silvery gray or metallic blue were shown at the International Furniture Fair in Milan in April and have landed in New York this month at Moss, 150 Greene Street (Houston Street).
